label: Simple launch + monitor
info:
# Simple launch + monitor workflow

This example shows the _'Launch workflow'_ and _'Monitor workflow'_ nodes.

The workflow nodes are pre-configured with some example configuration,
but you'll need to update this yourself to run the flow.

To get started:

1. Double click the _"Launch workflow"_ node to open the configuration.
2. Configure the Seqera Platform connection with your API token
3. Check & set the launchpad name and parameters
4. Set the configuration set for the _"Monitor workflow"_
5. Click "Deploy" in Node-RED, top right.

If everything is set up properly, you can launch the workflow and monitor its execution
by clicking the Inject node's tab on the left and following the _debug_ output in the
right hand sidebar.

name: Triggering a launch
info:
This is an example node that you can simply
click on to trigger a workflow launch.

You can replace this with an automated trigger
of your choice: a file being uploaded to AWS,
a Slack message, a time of day, a particular
weather forecast - whatever you can think of!

name: Launch
info:
This node launches a workflow on Seqera Platform.
Once launched, the node returns the response
from Platform.

For convenience, it can take the name of a pipeline
in your Seqera Platform Launchpad.
It fetches the pipeline details and uses this for launch.
If you prefer, you can also provide all of the workflow
details to the node directly instead of fetching from
the launchpad.

name: Check
info:
This node checks a workflow status on Seqera Platform.

There are three outputs - the first always emits the status.
The second emits if the workflow was successfuly and the third
emits if the workflow failed or was cancelled.

## Repeated checks

By default, this node keeps checking the workflow status
every 15 seconds (configurable) whilst it is in any
of the following states: Pending, Submitted, Running.

If your flow logic only needs it to check once, this
polling behaviour can be disabled.

name: Outputs
info:
For this example, the outputs from the workflow
status checks are passed to Node-RED _Debug_ nodes.

These print the payloads that they receive to the
"Debug" pane in the right hand sidebar.
This is useful to understand the outputs whilst building new flows.

For your Node-RED flows you'll probably want to replace these
with some other nodes that _do_ something.
